bibl.title: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Philip Showalter Hench, March 26, 1943

div1.p: Pinto has read Hemmeter's article on Carroll and is distressed by the developing disagreement over the recognition of Carroll's yellow fever work.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Philip Showalter Hench, March 26, 1943
div1.opener:
CITY OF OMAHA
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
OMAHA, NEB.
Mar. 26, 1943
____
A. S. PINTO, M. D.
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
A. GREENBERG, M. D.
DEPUTY HEALTH COMMISSIONER
N. H. ATTWOOD, M. D.
EMERGENCY PHYSICIAN
A. C. ANDERSEN, M. D.
DIRECTOR LABORATORIES
Lt. Col. P. S. Hench
Broadmore Hotel
Colorado Springs, Colo.
My Dear Dostor Hench:
div1.p:
I have read with a great deal of interest
the article on Maj. James Carroll by Dr. John C.
Hemeter, M.D., P.H.D., L.L.D. It distresses me very
much to find that an argument or disagreement has
cropped up from the good work accomplished by the
Yellow Fever Commission.

Dr. Carroll was an honorable gentleman,
and in my opinion a great deal of this controversy
has been engineered by over-enthusiastic friends
exagerating upon the statements of a mentally and
physically sick man.

I accompanied Dr. Carroll to New York in
1900. We left Havana, Cuba on the same boat, Oct.
10th of that year. During that trip I had ample
opportunity to observe his weakened and unreliable
condition.

I again saw him in Omaha, Nebraska in the
spring of 1904 or 1905, when he delivered the ad-
dress to the graduating class of the University of
Nebraska Medical School, and while I had some con-
versation with him, the condition of mind and body
were not much improved, if any, from when I put him
aboard a train to Washington, in New York in Oct-
ober, 1900.

I feel that while Dr. Carroll's work was
good, he was not the only one concerned in its exe-
cution and no more credit belongs to him than to
any other one who submitted to this experiment,
whether he contracted yellow fever or not. I would
not detract one iota from the credit due Dr. Carroll
for what he did, but to me it seems the broad mantle
of Charity should be spread over the falcities and
foibles of a mentally and physically sick enthusiast.
